Document.summary: The Document interface represents any web page loaded in the browser and serves as an entry point into the web page's content, which is the DOM tree.

remarks.para: The DOM tree includes elements such as body and table, among many others. It provides functionality globally to the document, like how to obtain the page's URL and create new elements in the document.

The Document interface describes the common properties and methods for any kind of document. Depending on the document's type (e.g., HTML, XML, SVG, …), a larger API is available: HTML documents, served with the "text/html" content type, also implement the interface, whereas XML and SVG documents implement the interface.

DocumentActiveElement.summary: The activeElement read-only property of the interface returns the within the DOM that is receiving keyboard events such as and . This is usually analogous to the focused element.

remarks.para: Which elements are focusable varies depending on the platform and the browser's current configuration. For example, on Safari, following the behavior of macOS, elements that aren't text input elements are not focusable by default, unless the "Full Keyboard Access" setting is enabled in System Preferences.

Typically a user can press the <kbd>Tab</kbd> key to move the focus around the page among focusable elements, and use keyboard gestures such as <kbd>Space</kbd> or <kbd>Enter</kbd> to simulate clicks on the focused element.

blockquote.para: Focus (which element is receiving user input events) is not the same thing as selection (the currently highlighted part of the document). You can get the current selection using .

DocumentActiveElement.value: The deepest which currently has focus.

DocumentAdoptedStyleSheets.summary: The adoptedStyleSheets property of the interface is used for setting an array of constructed stylesheets to be used by the document.

blockquote.para: A constructed stylesheet is a stylesheet created programmatically using the CSSStyleSheet() constructor (as compared to one created by a user-agent when importing a stylesheet from a script, imported using 'style' and {{CSSXref('@import')}}, or linked to via 'link').

remarks.para:
The same constructed stylesheets can also be shared with one or more instances using the ShadowRoot.adoptedStyleSheets property.
Changing an adopted stylesheet will affect all the objects that adopt it.

Stylesheets in the property are evaluated along with the document's other stylesheets using the CSS cascade algorithm.
Where the resolution of rules considers stylesheet order, adoptedStyleSheets are assumed to be ordered after those in Document.styleSheets.
Only stylesheets created using the CSSStyleSheet() constructor within the context of the current may be adopted.

-Constructable Stylesheets (web.dev)
-Using the Shadow DOM
-CSSStyleSheet() constructor
-
-
-
-

DocumentAdoptedStyleSheets.value: The value is an array of instances that must have been created using the constructor within the context of the same .If the array needs to be modified, use in-place mutations like push(). The instances themselves can also be modified, and these changes will apply wherever the stylesheet is adopted.In an earlier version of the specification, the array was not modifiable, so the only way to add new stylesheets was to assign a new array to adoptedStyleSheets.

DocumentAdoptNode.summary:
Document.adoptNode() transfers a node/dom from another {{domxref("Document", "document", "", "1")}} into the method's document.
The adopted node and its subtree are removed from their original document (if any), and their is changed to the current document.
The node can then be inserted into the current document.
DocumentAdoptNode.returns:
The copied importedNode in the scope of the importing document.After calling this method, importedNode and
externalNode are the same object.
NOTEimportedNode's
is null, since it has not yet been
inserted into the document tree!

DocumentAfterscriptexecute.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The afterscriptexecute event fires when a static {{HTMLElement("script")}} element finishes executing its script. It does not fire if the element is added dynamically, such as with .

remarks.para:
- event of Document
-

DocumentAlinkColor.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated Returns or sets the color of an active link in the document body. A link is active
during the time between mousedown and mouseup events.
DocumentAlinkColor.value: A string containing the name of the color (e.g., blue, darkblue, etc.) or the hexadecimal value of the color (e.g., #0000FF).When set to the null value, that null value is converted to the empty string (""), so document.alinkColor = null is equivalent to document.alinkColor = "".

DocumentAll.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The interface's read-only all property returns an rooted at the document node.

remarks.para: Rather than using document.all to return an of all the document's elements in document order, you can use to return a of all the document's elements in document order:

DocumentAll.value: An which contains every element in the document.

DocumentAnchors.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The anchors read-only property of the
interface returns a list of all of the anchors in the document.

DocumentAppend.summary:
The Document.append() method
inserts a set of objects or strings after
the last child of the document. Strings
are inserted as equivalent nodes.

remarks.para: This method appends a child to a Document. To append to an arbitrary element in the tree, see .

DocumentApplets.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The applets property of the returns an empty . This property is kept only for compatibility reasons; in older versions of browsers, it returned a list of the applets within a document.

blockquote.para:
Support for the <applet> element has been removed by all browsers. Therefore, calling document.applets always
returns an empty collection.

DocumentBeforescriptexecute.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The beforescriptexecute event fires when a static {{HTMLElement("script")}} is about to start executing. It does not fire if the element is added dynamically, such as with .

remarks.para:
- event of Document
-

DocumentBgColor.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The deprecated bgColor property gets or sets the background color of the
current document.
DocumentBgColor.value: A string representing the color as a word (e.g., "red") or hexadecimal value (e.g., "#ff0000").When set to the null value, that null value is converted to the empty string (""), so document.bgColor = null is equivalent to document.bgColor = "".

DocumentBody.summary:
The Document.body property represents the
body or frameset node of the current document, or
null if no such element exists.

summary.blockquote: WARNINGThis feature is currently opposed by two browser vendors. See the Standards positions section below for details of opposition.

blockquote.para: An Enrollment process is required to use this feature in your applications.

remarks.para: The browsingTopics() method of the interface returns a promise that fulfills with an array of objects representing the top topics for the user, one from each of the last three epochs. These topics could then be returned to the ad tech platform in a subsequent fetch request. By default, the method also causes the browser to record the current page visit as observed by the caller, so the page's hostname can later be used in topics calculation.
See Using the Topics API for more details.

blockquote.para: browsingTopics() does not rely on HTTP headers to send topics and mark topics as observed like the other Topics API enabling features, but it is somewhat less performant. You are advised to use one of the HTTP header-using features, falling back to browsingTopics() only in situations where the headers cannot be modified.

remarks.para: -Topics API

DocumentBrowsingTopics.returns: A that fulfills with an array of up to three objects representing the current user's selected topics for the last three epochs. Each object contains the following properties:The exact property values may vary by browser implementation. An example object from Chrome might look as follows:

DocumentCaretPositionFromPoint.summary: The caretPositionFromPoint() method of the interface returns a object, containing the DOM node, along with the caret and caret's character offset within that node.
DocumentCaretPositionFromPoint.returns: A object or null.The returned value is null if there is no viewport associated with the document, if the x or y are negative or outside of the viewport region, or if the coordinates indicate a point where no text insertion point indicator could be inserted.

DocumentCaretRangeFromPoint.summary:
CAUTION Non-standard The caretRangeFromPoint() method of the
interface returns a object for the document
fragment under the specified coordinates.

remarks.para: This method is the WebKit-proprietary implementation of the method.

DocumentCharacterSet.summary:
The Document.characterSet
read-only property returns the character encoding of the
document that it's currently rendered with.

blockquote.para:
A "character set" and a "character encoding" are related, but different. Despite the
name of this property, it returns the encoding.

DocumentChildElementCount.summary:
The Document.childElementCount read-only property
returns the number of child elements of the document.

remarks.para: To get the number of children of a specific element, see .

DocumentChildren.summary:
The read-only children property returns a live
which contains all of the child of the document upon which it was called.

remarks.para: For HTML documents, this is usually only the root <html> element.
See for child elements of specific HTML elements within the document.

DocumentChildren.value:
An which is a live, ordered collection of the DOM
elements which are children of the current document. You can access the
individual child nodes in the collection by using either the
method on the collection, or by using
JavaScript array-style notation.If the document has no element children, then children is an empty list with a
length of 0.

DocumentClear.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The Document.clear() method does nothing, but doesn't raise any error.

DocumentClose.summary:
The Document.close() method finishes writing to a
document, opened with .

DocumentCompatMode.summary:
The Document.compatMode read-only property indicates
whether the document is rendered in Quirks mode or
Standards mode.

DocumentContentType.summary:
The Document.contentType read-only property returns the
MIME type that the document is being rendered as. This may come from HTTP headers or
other sources of MIME information, and might be affected by automatic type conversions
performed by either the browser or extensions.

blockquote.para:
This property is unaffected by meta
elements.

DocumentCookie.summary:
The property cookie lets you read and write cookies associated with the document.
It serves as a getter and setter for the actual values of the cookies.

remarks.para:
-HTTP cookies
-DOM Storage
-URL.pathname
-
-RFC 2965

DocumentCookie.value:
A string containing a semicolon-separated list of all cookies (i.e., key=value pairs).
Note that each key and value may be surrounded by whitespace (space and tab characters): in fact, {{RFC(6265)}} mandates a single space after each semicolon, but some user agents may not abide by this.You can also assign to this property a string of the form "key=value", specifying the cookie to set/update. Note that you can only set/update a single cookie at a time using this method. Consider also that:
NOTEAs you can see from the code above, document.cookie is an accessor property with native setter and getter functions, and consequently is not a data property with a value: what you write is not the same as what you read, everything is always mediated by the JavaScript interpreter.

DocumentCreateAttribute.summary:
The Document.createAttribute() method creates a new
attribute node, and returns it. The object created is a node implementing the
interface. The DOM does not enforce what sort of attributes can be
added to a particular element in this manner.

blockquote.para: The string given in parameter is converted to lowercase.

DocumentCreateAttributeNS.summary:
The Document.createAttributeNS() method creates a new attribute node
with the specified namespace URI and qualified name, and returns it.
The object created is a node implementing the
interface. The DOM does not enforce what sort of attributes can be
added to a particular element in this manner.

DocumentCreateCDATASection.summary:
createCDATASection() creates a new CDATA section node,
and returns it.

DocumentCreateComment.summary:
createComment() creates a new comment node, and returns
it.

DocumentCreateDocumentFragment.summary:
Creates a new empty into which
DOM nodes can be added to build an offscreen DOM tree.
DocumentCreateDocumentFragment.returns:
A newly created, empty, object, which is ready to have
nodes inserted into it.

DocumentCreateElement.summary: In an HTML document, the document.createElement() method creates the HTML element specified by localName, or an if localName isn't recognized.

remarks.para:
-
-
-
-
-
- — to explicitly specify the namespace URI for the element.

DocumentCreateElement.returns:
The new .
NOTEA new {{domxref("HTMLElement", "HTMLElement", "", "1")}} is returned if the document is an {{domxref("HTMLDocument", "HTMLDocument", , "1")}}, which is the most common case. Otherwise a new {{domxref("Element","Element",,"1")}} is returned.

DocumentCreateElementNS.summary: Creates an element with the specified namespace URI and qualified name.

remarks.para:
To create an element without specifying a namespace URI, use the
method.

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGMany methods used with createEvent, such as initCustomEvent, are deprecated.
Use event constructors instead.

remarks.para:
Creates an event of the type specified. The
returned object should be first initialized and can then be passed to
.
-Creating and triggering events

DocumentCreateExpression.summary: This method compiles an which can then be used for (repeated) evaluations.

remarks.para: You must call this method on the same document that you run the expression against.

DocumentCreateNodeIterator.summary: The Document.createNodeIterator() method returns a new NodeIterator object.

DocumentCreateNSResolver.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The createNSResolver() method of the interface used to create a custom XPathNSResolver object. It now returns the input as-is and is only kept for compatibility reasons.

remarks.para:
-
-Introduction to using XPath in JavaScript

DocumentCreateProcessingInstruction.summary: createProcessingInstruction() generates a new processing instruction node and returns it.

remarks.para: The new node usually will be inserted into an XML document in order to accomplish anything with it, such as with .

DocumentCreateRange.summary:
The Document.createRange() method returns a new
object.

DocumentCreateTextNode.summary:
Creates a new node. This method can be used to escape HTML
characters.

DocumentCreateTouch.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The Document.createTouch() method creates and returns a new object.

blockquote.para: Use the constructor.

remarks.para:
-Touch events
-
-
-

DocumentCreateTouchList.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The Document.createTouchList() method creates and returns a new object.

remarks.para:
-Touch events
-
-
-
-

DocumentCreateTreeWalker.summary: The Document.createTreeWalker() creator method returns a newly created object.

remarks.para: -: Related interface

DocumentCurrentScript.summary: The Document.currentScript property returns the script element whose script is currently being processed and isn't a JavaScript module. (For modules use import.meta instead.)

remarks.para:
It's important to note that this will not reference the script
element if the code in the script is being called as a callback or event handler; it
will only reference the element while it's initially being processed.

-import.meta
-script
- event of Document
- event of Document

DocumentDefaultView.summary:
In browsers, document.defaultView returns the
object associated with {{Glossary("Browsing_context", "a document")}}, or null if none is available.

remarks.para: This property is read-only.

DocumentDesignMode.summary:
document.designMode controls whether the entire document
is editable. Valid values are "on" and "off". According to the
specification, this property is meant to default to "off". Firefox follows
this standard. The earlier versions of Chrome and IE default to "inherit".
Starting in Chrome 43, the default is "off" and "inherit" is
no longer supported. In IE6-10, the value is capitalized.
DocumentDesignMode.value:
A string indicating whether designMode is (or should be) set to on or off.
Valid values are on and off.

DocumentDir.summary:
The Document.dir property is a string
representing the directionality of the text of the document, whether left to right
(default) or right to left. Possible values are 'rtl', right to left, and
'ltr', left to right.

remarks.para:
-dir global
attribute

DocumentDoctype.summary: The doctype read-only property of the interface is a object representing the {{glossary("Doctype", "Document Type Declaration (DTD)")}} associated with the current document.

DocumentDocument.summary:
The Document constructor creates a new
object that is a web page loaded in the browser and serving as
an entry point into the page's content.

DocumentDocumentElement.summary:
The documentElement read-only property of the interface returns the
that is the root element of the (for
example, the html element for HTML documents).

DocumentDocumentURI.summary:
The documentURI read-only property of the
interface returns the document location as a string.

remarks.para: -The property which returns the same value.

DocumentDomain.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The domain property of the
interface gets/sets the domain portion of the origin of the current
document, as used by the same-origin policy.

remarks.para:
-Same-origin policy
-
-
-

DocumentDOMContentLoaded.summary: The DOMContentLoaded event fires when the HTML document has been completely parsed, and all deferred scripts (<script defer src="…"> and <script type="module">) have downloaded and executed. It doesn't wait for other things like images, subframes, and async scripts to finish loading.

remarks.para: DOMContentLoaded does not wait for stylesheets to load, however deferred scripts do wait for stylesheets, and the DOMContentLoaded event is queued after deferred scripts. Also, scripts which aren't deferred or async (e.g., <script>) will wait for already-parsed stylesheets to load.
A different event, , should be used only to detect a fully-loaded page. It is a common mistake to use load where DOMContentLoaded would be more appropriate.
This event is not cancelable.
-Related events: , , ,

DocumentElementFromPoint.summary:
The elementFromPoint()
method, available on the object, returns the topmost at the specified coordinates
(relative to the viewport).

remarks.para:
If the element at the specified point belongs to another document (for example, the
document of an iframe), that document's parent element is returned
(the <iframe> itself). If the element at the given point is anonymous
or XBL generated content, such as a textbox's scroll bars, then the first non-anonymous
ancestor element (for example, the textbox) is returned.

Elements with pointer-events set to none will be ignored,
and the element below it will be returned.

If the method is run on another document (like an <iframe>'s
subdocument), the coordinates are relative to the document where the method is being
called.

If the specified point is outside the visible bounds of the document or either
coordinate is negative, the result is null.

If you need to find the specific position inside the element, use
.

DocumentElementFromPoint.returns: The topmost object located at the specified coordinates.

DocumentElementsFromPoint.summary:
The elementsFromPoint() method
of the interface returns an array of all elements
at the specified coordinates (relative to the viewport).
The elements are ordered from the topmost to the bottommost box of the viewport.

remarks.para: It operates in a similar way to the method.

DocumentElementsFromPoint.returns: An array of objects, ordered from the topmost to the bottommost box of the viewport.

DocumentEmbeds.summary:
The embeds read-only property of the
interface returns a list of the embedded
embed elements within the current document.

DocumentEnableStyleSheetsForSet.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated Enables the style sheets matching the specified name in the current style sheet set,
and disables all other style sheets (except those without a title, which are always
enabled).

DocumentEvaluate.summary:
The evaluate() method of the interface selects elements based on the XPath
expression given in parameters.

remarks.para: XPath expressions can be evaluated on both HTML and XML documents.

DocumentEvaluate.returns:
An linking to the selected nodes. If result was null, it is a new object,
if not, it is the same object as the one passed as the result parameter.

DocumentExecCommand.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The execCommand method implements multiple different commands. Some of them provide access to the clipboard, while others are for editing form inputs, contenteditable elements or entire documents (when switched to design mode).

remarks.para: To access the clipboard, the newer Clipboard API is recommended over execCommand(). However, there is no replacement for the editing commands: unlike direct DOM manipulation, modifications performed by execCommand() preserve the undo buffer (edit history).

Most commands affect the document's selection. For example, some commands (bold, italics, etc.) format the currently selected text, while others delete the selection, insert new elements (replacing the selection) or affect an entire line (indenting). Only the currently active editable element can be modified, but some commands (e.g., copy) can work without an editable element.

blockquote.para: Modifications performed by execCommand() may or may not trigger and events, depending on the browser and configuration. If triggered, the handlers for the events will run before execCommand() returns. Authors need to be careful about such recursive calls, especially if they call execCommand() in response to these events. From Firefox 82, nested execCommand() calls will always fail, see bug 1634262.

remarks.para:
-Clipboard API
-MDN example: execCommands supported in your browser
-
-

DocumentExecCommand.returns:
A boolean value that is false if the command is unsupported or disabled.
NOTEdocument.execCommand() only returns
true if it is invoked as part of a user interaction. You can't use it to
verify browser support before calling a command.

DocumentExitFullscreen.summary:
The method
exitFullscreen() requests that the element on this
document which is currently being presented in fullscreen mode be taken out of
fullscreen mode, restoring the previous state of the screen. This usually
reverses the effects of a previous call to .

remarks.para:
-Fullscreen API
-Guide to the Fullscreen API
-
-
-:fullscreen and {{cssxref("::backdrop")}}
-The iframe allowfullscreen
attribute

DocumentExitFullscreen.returns:
A which is resolved once the {{Glossary("user agent")}} has
finished exiting fullscreen mode. If an error occurs while attempting to exit
fullscreen mode, the catch() handler for the promise is called.

DocumentExitPictureInPicture.summary:
The exitPictureInPicture() method of the interface
requests that a video contained
in this document, which is currently floating, be taken out of picture-in-picture
mode, restoring the previous state of the screen. This usually reverses the
effects of a previous call to .

remarks.para:
-
-
-
-
-:picture-in-picture
-Picture-in-Picture events

DocumentExitPictureInPicture.returns:
A , which is resolved once the {{Glossary("user agent")}} has
finished exiting picture-in-picture mode. If an error occurs while attempting to exit
fullscreen mode, the catch() handler for the promise is called.

DocumentExitPointerLock.summary: The exitPointerLock() method of the interface asynchronously releases a pointer lock previously requested through .

blockquote.para: While the exitPointerLock() method is called on the document, the requestPointerLock() method is called on an element.

remarks.para: To track the success or failure of the request, it is necessary to listen for the and events.

-
-
-Pointer Lock

DocumentFeaturePolicy.summary: NOTE Experimental The featurePolicy read-only property of the interface returns the interface which provides a simple API for inspecting the Permissions Policies applied to a specific document.
DocumentFeaturePolicy.value: A object that can be used to inspect the Permissions Policy settings applied to the document.

DocumentFgColor.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated fgColor gets/sets the foreground color, or text color, of
the current document.
DocumentFgColor.value: A string representing the color as a word (e.g., "red") or hexadecimal value (e.g., "#ff0000").

DocumentFirstElementChild.summary:
The Document.firstElementChild read-only property
returns the document's first child , or null if there
are no child elements.

remarks.para: For HTML documents, this is usually the only child, the root <html> element.
See for the first child element of specific elements within a document.

DocumentFonts.summary: The fonts property of the interface returns the interface of the document.

remarks.para: This feature is part of the CSS Font Loading API.

- interface
-

DocumentFonts.value:
The returned value is the interface of the document.
The FontFaceSet interface is useful for loading new fonts, checking the status of previously loaded fonts etc.

DocumentForms.summary: The forms read-only property of the interface returns an listing all the {{HTMLElement("form")}} elements contained in the document.

blockquote.para: Similarly, you can access a list of a form's component user input elements using the property.

remarks.para:
You can also access named <form> elements as properties of the document object.
For example, document["login-form"] and document.forms["login-form"] can both be used to access the form named login-form.

blockquote.para:
Relying on the document["form-name"] pattern is dangerous and discouraged because it can lead to unexpected conflicts with existing or future APIs in the browser.
For example, if a browser introduces a built-in document["login-form"] property in the future, your code may no longer be able to access the form element.
To avoid such conflicts, always use document.forms to access named forms.

remarks.para:
-HTML forms
-{{HTMLElement("form")}} and the interface

DocumentForms.value:
An object listing all of the document's forms.
Each item in the collection is a representing a single <form> element.If the document has no forms, the returned collection is empty, with a length of zero.

DocumentFragmentDirective.summary: The fragmentDirective read-only property of the interface returns the for the current document.

remarks.para:
-Text fragments
-{{cssxref("::target-text")}}

DocumentFullscreen.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The obsolete interface's fullscreen read-only property reports whether or not the document is currently displaying content in fullscreen mode.

remarks.para: Although this property is read-only, it will not throw if it is modified (even in strict mode); the setter is a no-operation and it will be ignored.

blockquote.para: Since this property is deprecated, you can determine if fullscreen mode is active on the document by checking to see if is not null.

remarks.para:
-Fullscreen API
-Guide to the Fullscreen API
-

DocumentFullscreen.value: A Boolean value which is true if the document is currently displaying an element in fullscreen mode; otherwise, the value is false.

DocumentFullscreenchange.summary: The fullscreenchange event is fired immediately after the browser switches into or out of fullscreen mode.

remarks.para: The event is sent to the Element that is transitioning into or out of fullscreen mode, and this event then bubbles up to the Document.

To find out whether the Element is entering or exiting fullscreen mode, check the value of : if this value is null then the element is exiting fullscreen mode, otherwise it is entering fullscreen mode.
This event is not cancelable.

-
-: event
-Fullscreen API
-Guide to the Fullscreen API

DocumentFullscreenElement.summary:
The
Document.fullscreenElement read-only
property returns the that is currently being presented in
fullscreen mode in this document, or null if fullscreen mode is not
currently in use.

remarks.para:
Although this property is read-only, it will not throw if it is modified (even in
strict mode); the setter is a no-operation and it will be ignored.

-Fullscreen API
-Guide to the Fullscreen API
-
-
-:fullscreen and {{cssxref("::backdrop")}}
-The iframe allowfullscreen
attribute

DocumentFullscreenElement.value:
The object that's currently in fullscreen mode; if fullscreen
mode isn't currently in use by the document, the returned
value is null. If there are multiple elements in fullscreen mode, the topmost (most recently requested) element is returned.

DocumentFullscreenEnabled.summary:
The read-only fullscreenEnabled
property on the interface indicates whether or not fullscreen
mode is available.

remarks.para:
fullscreen mode is available only for a page that has no
windowed plug-ins in any of its documents, and if all iframe elements
which contain the document have their allowfullscreen
attribute set.

Although this property is read-only, it will not throw if it is modified (even in
strict mode); the setter is a no-operation and it will be ignored.

-Fullscreen API
-Guide to the Fullscreen API
-
-
-
-:fullscreen and {{cssxref("::backdrop")}}
-The iframe allowfullscreen
attribute

DocumentFullscreenEnabled.value:
A boolean value which is true if the document and the
elements within can be placed into fullscreen mode by calling
. If fullscreen mode isn't available, this
value is false.

DocumentFullscreenerror.summary: The fullscreenerror event is fired when the browser cannot switch to fullscreen mode.

remarks.para: As with the fullscreenchange event, two fullscreenerror events are fired; the first is sent to the which failed to change modes, and the second is sent to the which owns that element.
For some reasons that switching into fullscreen mode might fail, see the guide to the Fullscreen API.
This event is not cancelable.

-
-: event
-Fullscreen API
-Guide to the Fullscreen API

DocumentGetAnimations.summary:
The getAnimations() method of the interface
returns an array of all objects currently in effect whose
target elements are descendants of the document. This array includes CSS Animations, CSS Transitions, and Web Animations.

remarks.para:
-Web Animations API
-CSS Animations
-CSS Transitions
- - Fetch only the animations on a single
and its descendants.
-

DocumentGetAnimations.returns:
An {{jsxref("Array")}} of objects, each representing one
animation currently associated with elements which are descendants of the
on which it's called.

DocumentGetElementById.summary: The getElementById() method of the interface returns an object representing the element whose property matches the specified string. Since element IDs are required to be unique if specified, they're a useful way to get access to a specific element quickly.

remarks.para: If you need to get access to an element which doesn't have an ID, you can use to find the element using any {{Glossary("CSS selector", "selector")}}.

blockquote.para: IDs should be unique inside a document. If two or more elements in a document have the same ID, this method returns the first element found.

DocumentGetElementById.returns: An object describing the DOM element object matching the specified ID, or null if no matching element was found in the document.

DocumentGetElementsByClassName.summary:
The getElementsByClassName method of
interface returns an array-like object
of all child elements which have all of the given class name(s).

remarks.para:
When called on
the object, the complete document is searched, including the
root node. You may also call on any element; it will return only elements which are descendants of the specified root element with the given class name(s).

blockquote.para:
This is a live . Changes in the DOM will
reflect in the array as the changes occur. If an element selected by this array no
longer qualifies for the selector, it will automatically be removed. Be aware of this
for iteration purposes.

DocumentGetElementsByName.summary:
The getElementsByName() method
of the object returns a Collection of
elements with a given name attribute in the document.

remarks.para:
- to return a reference to an element by its
unique id
- to return references to elements with
the same tag name
- to return references to elements via CSS
selectors like 'div.myclass'

DocumentGetElementsByName.returns: A live collection, meaning it automatically updates as new elements with the same name are added to, or removed from, the document.

DocumentGetElementsByTagName.summary:
The getElementsByTagName method of
interface returns an
of elements with the given tag name.

remarks.para:
The complete
document is searched, including the root node. The returned HTMLCollection
is live, meaning that it updates itself automatically to stay in sync with the DOM tree
without having to call document.getElementsByTagName() again.

-
- to return a reference to an element by its
id
- to return a reference to an element by
its name
- for powerful selectors via queries like
'div.myclass'

DocumentGetElementsByTagName.returns: A live of found elements in the order they appear in the tree.

DocumentGetElementsByTagNameNS.summary:
Returns a list of elements with the given tag name belonging to the given namespace.
The complete document is searched, including the root node.
DocumentGetElementsByTagNameNS.returns: A live of found elements in the order they appear in the tree.

DocumentGetSelection.summary: The getSelection() method of the interface returns the object associated with this document, representing the range of text selected by the user, or the current position of the caret.
DocumentGetSelection.returns: A object, or null if the document has no browsing context (for example, it is the document of an iframe that is not attached to a document).

DocumentHasFocus.summary:
The hasFocus() method of the interface returns a boolean value indicating whether the document or any element inside the document has focus.
This method can be used to determine whether the active element in a document has focus.

blockquote.para:
When viewing a document, an element with focus is always the active element in the document, but an active element does not necessarily have focus.
For example, an active element within a popup window that is not the foreground doesn't have focus.

remarks.para:
-
-Using the Page Visibility API

DocumentHasFocus.returns:
false if the active element in the document has no focus;
true if the active element in the document has focus.

DocumentHasStorageAccess.summary: The hasStorageAccess() method of the interface returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves with a boolean value indicating whether the document has access to third-party, unpartitioned cookies.

remarks.para: This method is part of the Storage Access API.

blockquote.para: This method is another name for . There are no current plans to remove this method in favor of .

remarks.para:
-, ,
-Using the Storage Access API
-Introducing Storage Access API (WebKit blog)

DocumentHasStorageAccess.returns:
A that resolves with a boolean value indicating whether the document has access to third-party cookies — true if it does, and false if not.The result returned by this method can be inaccurate in a couple of circumstances:
NOTEIf the promise gets resolved and a user gesture event was being processed when the function was originally called, the resolve handler will run as if a user gesture was being processed, so it will be able to call APIs that require user activation.

DocumentHasUnpartitionedCookieAccess.summary: The hasUnpartitionedCookieAccess() method of the interface returns a {{jsxref("Promise")}} that resolves with a boolean value indicating whether the document has access to third-party, unpartitioned cookies.

remarks.para: This method is part of the Storage Access API.
This method is a new name for .

-, ,
-Using the Storage Access API
-Introducing Storage Access API (WebKit blog)

DocumentHasUnpartitionedCookieAccess.returns: A that resolves with a boolean value indicating whether the document has access to third-party cookies — true if it does, and false if not.See for more details.

DocumentHead.summary:
The head read-only property of
the interface returns the {{HTMLElement("head")}} element of
the current document.

DocumentHidden.summary:
The Document.hidden read-only property returns a Boolean
value indicating if the page is considered hidden or not.

remarks.para: The property provides an alternative way to determine whether the page is hidden.

DocumentHidden.value: A Boolean value, true if the page is hidden, and false otherwise.

DocumentImages.summary: The images read-only property of the interface returns a collection of the images in the current HTML document.
DocumentImages.value:
An providing a live list of all of the images contained in the current document.
Each entry in the collection is an representing a single image element.

DocumentImplementation.summary:
The Document.implementation property returns a
object associated with the current document.

DocumentImportNode.summary:
The object's importNode() method creates a copy of a
or from another document, to be
inserted into the current document later.

remarks.para:
The imported node is not yet included in the document tree. To include it, you need to
call an insertion method such as or
with a node that is
currently in the document tree.

Unlike , the original node is not removed from its
original document. The imported node is a clone of the original.

-, which behaves very similar to this method
-
-

DocumentImportNode.returns:
The copied importedNode in the scope of the importing document.
NOTEimportedNode's is null, since it has not yet been inserted into the document tree!

DocumentLastElementChild.summary:
The Document.lastElementChild read-only property
returns the document's last child , or null if there
are no child elements.

remarks.para: For HTML documents, this is usually the only child, the root <html> element.
See for the last child element of specific elements within a document.

DocumentLastModified.summary:
The lastModified property of the
interface returns a string containing the date and local time on which the current document
was last modified.

DocumentLastStyleSheetSet.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The Document.lastStyleSheetSet property returns the last enabled style sheet set. This property's
value changes whenever the property is
changed.
DocumentLastStyleSheetSet.value:
The style sheet set that was most recently set. If the current style sheet set has not been changed by setting , the returned value is null.
NOTEThis value doesn't change when
is called.

DocumentLinkColor.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The Document.linkColor property gets/sets the color of
links within the document.

remarks.para:
This property is deprecated. As an alternative, you can set the CSS
{{cssxref("color")}} property on either HTML anchor links (a) or on
:link pseudo-classes.

DocumentLinkColor.value: A string representing the color as a word (e.g., red) or hexadecimal value (e.g., #ff0000).When set to the null value, that null value is converted to the empty string (""), so document.linkColor = null is equivalent to document.linkColor = "".

DocumentLinks.summary: The links read-only property of the interface returns a collection of all {{HTMLElement("area")}} elements and {{HTMLElement("a")}} elements in a document with a value for the href attribute.

DocumentLocation.summary:
The Document.location read-only property returns a
object, which contains information about the URL of the document
and provides methods for changing that URL and loading another URL.

remarks.para:
Though Document.location is a read-only Location
object, you can also assign a string to it. This means that you can
work with document.location as if it were a string in most cases:
document.location = 'http://www.example.com' is a synonym of
document.location.href = 'http://www.example.com'. If you assign another
string to it, browser will load the website you assigned.

To retrieve just the URL as a string, the read-only
property can also be used.

If the current document is not in a browsing context, the returned value is
null.

-The interface of the returned value,
-A similar information, but attached to the browsing context,

DocumentMoveBefore.summary: NOTE Experimental The moveBefore() method of the interface moves a given inside the Document DOM node as a direct child, before a given reference node.

DocumentMozSetImageElement.summary:
CAUTION Non-standard The Document.mozSetImageElement() method changes the
element being used as the CSS background for a background with a given background
element ID.

remarks.para: -element

DocumentOpen.summary:
The Document.open() method opens a document for
{{domxref("Document.write", "writing", "", "1")}}.

remarks.para: This does come with some side effects. For example:

DocumentParseHTMLUnsafe.summary: The parseHTMLUnsafe() static method of the object is used to parse an HTML input, optionally filtering unwanted HTML elements and attributes, in order to create a new instance.

remarks.para: Unlike with , XSS-unsafe HTML entities are not guaranteed to be removed.

-
- and
- and
- for parsing HTML or XML into a DOM tree
-HTML Sanitizer API

DocumentParseHTML.summary: The parseHTML() static method of the object provides an XSS-safe method to parse and sanitize a string of HTML in order to create a new instance.

remarks.para:
-
- and
- and
- for parsing HTML or XML into a DOM tree
-HTML Sanitizer API

DocumentPictureInPictureElement.summary:
The read-only pictureInPictureElement property of the
interface returns the that is currently being
presented in picture-in-picture mode in this document, or null if
picture-in-picture mode is not currently in use.

remarks.para:
Although this property is read-only, it will not throw if it is modified (even in
strict mode); the setter is a no-operation and will be ignored.

-
-
-
-
-:picture-in-picture

DocumentPictureInPictureElement.value: A reference to the object that's currently in picture-in-picture mode.Returns null if the document has no associated element in picture-in-picture mode. For example, there's no picture-in-picture element, or the element is from an iframe.

DocumentPictureInPictureEnabled.summary:
The read-only
pictureInPictureEnabled property of the
interface indicates whether or not picture-in-picture mode is
available.

remarks.para:
Picture-in-Picture mode is available by default unless specified
otherwise by a Permissions-Policy.

Although this property is read-only, it will not throw if it is modified (even in
strict mode); the setter is a no-operation and will be ignored.

-
-
-
-
-:picture-in-picture

DocumentPictureInPictureEnabled.value:
A boolean value, which is true if a video can enter
picture-in-picture and be displayed in a floating window by calling
. If picture-in-picture mode isn't
available, this value is false.

DocumentPlugins.summary:
The plugins read-only property of the
interface returns an object
containing one or more s representing the
embed elements in the current document.

blockquote.para:
For a list of installed plugins, use Navigator.plugins
instead.

DocumentPointerlockchange.summary: The pointerlockchange event is fired when the pointer is locked/unlocked.

remarks.para: The event handler can use to determine whether the pointer is locked, and if so, to which element it is locked.
This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.
-Using Pointer Lock API

DocumentPointerLockElement.summary:
The pointerLockElement read-only property of the interface provides the element set as the target for mouse events while the pointer is locked.
It is null if lock is pending, pointer is unlocked, or the target is in another document.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Pointer Lock

DocumentPointerlockerror.summary: The pointerlockerror event is fired when locking the pointer failed (for technical reasons or because the permission was denied).

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.
-Using Pointer Lock API

DocumentPreferredStyleSheetSet.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The preferredStyleSheetSet property returns the preferred style sheet set as set by the page
author.
DocumentPreferredStyleSheetSet.value:
The author's preferred style sheet set. This is determined from the order of style sheet declarations and the
Default-Style HTTP header.If there isn't a preferred style sheet set defined by the author, the empty string ("") is returned.

DocumentPrepend.summary:
The Document.prepend() method
inserts a set of objects or strings before
the first child of the document. Strings
are inserted as equivalent nodes.

remarks.para: This method prepends a child to a Document. To prepend to an arbitrary element in the tree, see .

DocumentPrerendering.summary: NOTE Experimental The prerendering read-only property of the interface returns true if the document is currently in the process of prerendering, as initiated via the Speculation Rules API.

remarks.para:
-Speculation Rules API
- event
- property

DocumentPrerendering.value: A boolean. Returns true if the document is currently in the process of prerendering, and false if it is not. false will be returned for documents that have finished prerendering, and documents that were not prerendered.

DocumentPrerenderingchange.summary: NOTE Experimental The prerenderingchange event is fired on a prerendered document when it is activated (i.e., the user views the page).

remarks.para:
-Speculation Rules API
- property
- property

DocumentQueryCommandEnabled.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The Document.queryCommandEnabled() method reports whether
or not the specified editor command is enabled by the browser.
DocumentQueryCommandEnabled.returns:
Returns a boolean value which is true if the command is enabled
and false if the command isn't.

DocumentQueryCommandState.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The queryCommandState() method will tell you if the current selection has a certain command applied.

remarks.para:
-
-
-Browser bugs related to queryCommandState(): Scribe's "Browser Inconsistencies" documentation

DocumentQueryCommandState.returns: queryCommandState() can return a boolean value or null if the state is unknown.

DocumentQueryCommandSupported.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The Document.queryCommandSupported() method reports
whether or not the specified editor command is supported by the browser.
DocumentQueryCommandSupported.returns:
Returns a boolean value which is true if the command is supported
and false if the command isn't.

DocumentQuerySelector.summary:
The method querySelector()
returns the first within the document that matches the specified
CSS selector, or group of CSS selectors. If no matches are found, null is returned.

remarks.para: The matching is done using depth-first pre-order traversal of the document's nodes starting with the first element in the document's markup and iterating through sequential nodes by order of the number of child nodes.

If the specified selector matches an ID that is incorrectly used more than once in the
document, the first element with that ID is returned.
CSS pseudo-elements will never return any elements.

-Locating DOM elements using selectors
-
-
-

DocumentQuerySelector.returns:
An object representing the first element in the document
that matches the specified set of CSS selectors, or null is returned if there are no matches.If you need a list of all elements matching the specified selectors, you should use
instead.

DocumentQuerySelectorAll.summary:
The method querySelectorAll()
returns a static (not live) representing a list of the
document's elements that match the specified group of selectors.

remarks.para:
-Locating DOM elements using selectors
-Attribute selectors in the CSS
Guide
-Attribute selectors in the MDN Learning Area
- and
-
- and

DocumentQuerySelectorAll.returns:
A non-live containing one object for
each element that matches at least one of the specified selectors or an empty
in case of no matches. The elements are in document order — that is, parents before children, earlier siblings before later siblings.
NOTEIf the specified selectors include a CSS pseudo-element, the returned list
is always empty.

DocumentReadyState.summary:
The Document.readyState property describes the loading state of the .
When the value of this property changes, a event fires on the object.

remarks.para:
-Related events:-
-
-

DocumentReadyState.value: The readyState of a document can be one of following:

DocumentReadystatechange.summary: The readystatechange event is fired when the attribute of a document has changed.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.
-Related events: DOMContentLoaded, load, beforeunload, unload

DocumentReferrer.summary:
The Document.referrer property returns the URI of the page that linked to
this page.
DocumentReferrer.value:
The value is an empty string if the user navigated to the page directly (not through a
link, but, for example, by using a bookmark). Because this property returns only a
string, it doesn't give you document object model (DOM) access to the referring page.Inside an iframe, the Document.referrer will initially
be set to the of the parent's
in same-origin requests.
In cross-origin requests, it's the of the parent's Window.location by default.
For more information, see the Referrer-Policy: strict-origin-when-cross-origin documentation.

DocumentReleaseCapture.summary:
CAUTION Non-standard The releaseCapture() method releases mouse capture if
it's currently enabled on an element within this document.
Once mouse capture is released, mouse events will no longer all be directed to the element on which capture is enabled.

remarks.para: Enabling mouse capture on an element is done by calling .

DocumentReplaceChildren.summary:
The Document.replaceChildren() method replaces the
existing children of a Document with a specified new set of children.

DocumentRequestStorageAccess.summary: The requestStorageAccess() method of the interface allows content loaded in a third-party context (i.e., embedded in an {{htmlelement("iframe")}}) to request access to third-party cookies and unpartitioned state. This is relevant to user agents that, by default, block access to third-party, unpartitioned cookies to improve privacy (e.g., to prevent tracking), and is part of the Storage Access API.

remarks.para: To check whether permission to access third-party cookies has already been granted, you can call , specifying the feature name "storage-access".

blockquote.para: Usage of this feature may be blocked by a Permissions-Policy/storage-access Permissions Policy set on your server. In addition, the document must pass additional browser-specific checks such as allowlists, blocklists, on-device classification, user settings, anti-clickjacking heuristics, or prompting the user for explicit permission.

remarks.para:
-, ,
-Using the Storage Access API
-Introducing Storage Access API (WebKit blog)

DocumentRequestStorageAccess.returns: A that fulfills with undefined if the access to third-party cookies was granted and no types parameter was provided, fulfills with if the access to unpartitioned state requested by the types parameter was provided, and rejects if access was denied.requestStorageAccess() requests are automatically denied unless the embedded content is currently processing a user gesture such as a tap or click (transient activation), or unless permission was already granted previously. If permission was not previously granted, they need to be run inside a user gesture-based event handler. The user gesture behavior depends on the state of the promise:

DocumentRequestStorageAccessFor.summary: NOTE Experimental The requestStorageAccessFor() method of the interface allows top-level sites to request third-party cookie access on behalf of embedded content originating from another site in the same related website set. It returns a that resolves if the access was granted, and rejects if access was denied.

remarks.para:
-, ,
-Using the Storage Access API
-Introducing Storage Access API (WebKit blog)

DocumentRequestStorageAccessFor.returns: A that fulfills with undefined if the access to third-party cookies was granted and rejects if access was denied.requestStorageAccessFor() requests are automatically denied unless the top-level content is currently processing a user gesture such as a tap or click (transient activation), or unless permission was already granted previously. If permission was not previously granted, they must run inside a user gesture-based event handler. The user gesture behavior depends on the state of the promise:

DocumentRootElement.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated Document.rootElement returns the
that is the root element of the if it is an
svg element, otherwise null. It is deprecated in favor of
, which returns the root element for all
documents.
DocumentRootElement.value:
For SVG elements, the that is the root element of the ; otherwise null.If the document is a non-empty SVG document, then the rootElement will be
an , identical to the documentElement.

DocumentScripts.summary:
The scripts property of the
interface returns a list of the script
elements in the document. The returned object is an
.
DocumentScripts.value:
An . You can use this just like an array to get all the
elements in the list.

DocumentScrollend.summary:
The scrollend event fires when the document view has completed scrolling.
Scrolling is considered completed when the scroll position has no more pending updates and the user has completed their gesture.

remarks.para:
Scroll position updates include smooth or instant mouse wheel scrolling, keyboard scrolling, scroll-snap events, or other APIs and gestures which cause the scroll position to update.
User gestures like touch panning or trackpad scrolling aren't complete until pointers or keys have released.
If the scroll position did not change, then no scrollend event fires.
For detecting when scrolling inside an element is complete, see the event of Element.

-Document scroll event
-Element scrollend event
-Element scroll event

DocumentScrollingElement.summary:
The scrollingElement read-only property of the
interface returns a reference to the that
scrolls the document. In standards mode, this is the root element of the
document, .

remarks.para:
When in quirks mode, the scrollingElement attribute returns the HTML
body element if it exists and is not potentially scrollable, otherwise it returns null. This may look surprising but is true according to both the specification and browsers.

DocumentScrollingElement.value: The that scrolls the document, usually the root element (unless not in standard mode).

DocumentScrollsnapchange.summary: NOTE Experimental The scrollsnapchange event of the interface is fired on the document scroll container at the end of a scrolling operation when a new scroll snap target is selected.

remarks.para: This event works in much the same way as the interface's scrollsnapchange event, except that the overall HTML document has to be set as the scroll snap container (i.e., {{cssxref("scroll-snap-type")}} is set on the html element).

- event
- event
-
-CSS scroll-snap-type property
-CSS scroll snap module
-Using scroll snap events
-Scroll Snap Events on developer.chrome.com (2024)

DocumentScrollsnapchanging.summary: NOTE Experimental The scrollsnapchanging event of the interface is fired on the scroll container when the browser determines a new scroll snap target is pending, i.e., it will be selected when the current scroll gesture ends.

remarks.para: This event works in much the same way as the interface's scrollsnapchanging event, except that the overall HTML document has to be set as the scroll snap container (i.e., {{cssxref("scroll-snap-type")}} is set on the html element).

- event
- event
-
-CSS scroll-snap-type property
-CSS scroll snap module
-Using scroll snap events
-Scroll Snap Events on developer.chrome.com (2024)

DocumentScroll.summary:
The scroll event fires when the document view has been scrolled.
To detect when scrolling has completed, see the event of Document.
For element scrolling, see event of Element.

remarks.para:
-Document: scrollend event
-Element: scroll event
-Element: scrollend event

DocumentSecuritypolicyviolation.summary: The securitypolicyviolation event is fired when a Content Security Policy is violated.

remarks.para: The event is fired on the document when there is a violation of the document CSP policy (and may also bubble from elements in the document).
This event bubbles to the object, and is composed.

blockquote.para:
You should generally add the handler for this event to a top level object (i.e., or ).
While HTML elements can technically be the target of the securitypolicyviolation event, in reality this event does not fire on them—for example, a blocked <img> source directly triggers this event on document as the target, instead of bubbling from the <img> element.

remarks.para:
-The event of the interface
-The event of the interface
-HTTP > Content Security Policy

DocumentSelectedStyleSheetSet.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The selectedStyleSheetSet property indicates the name of the style sheet set that's currently in use.
DocumentSelectedStyleSheetSet.value:
The name of the style sheet set currently in use. You can also set the current style sheet set using this property.Setting the value of this property is equivalent to calling
with the value of
currentStyleSheetSet, then setting the value of
lastStyleSheetSet to that value as well.
NOTEThis attribute's value is live; directly changing
the disabled attribute on style sheets will affect the value of this
attribute.

DocumentSelectionchange.summary: The selectionchange event of the Selection API is fired when the current of a is changed.

remarks.para: This event is not cancelable and does not bubble.
The event can be handled by adding an event listener for selectionchange or using the onselectionchange event handler.

blockquote.para: This event is not quite the same as the selectionchange events fired when the text selection in an {{HTMLElement("input")}} or {{HTMLElement("textarea")}} element is changed. See the event of HTMLInputElement for more details.

DocumentStartViewTransition.summary: The startViewTransition() method of the interface starts a new same-document (SPA) view transition and returns a object to represent it.

remarks.para: When startViewTransition() is invoked, a sequence of steps is followed as explained in The view transition process.

-:active-view-transition pseudo-class
-:active-view-transition-type pseudo-class
-Smooth transitions with the View Transition API

DocumentStyleSheets.summary: The styleSheets read-only property of the interface returns a of objects, for stylesheets explicitly linked into or embedded in a document.
DocumentStyleSheets.value: The returned list is ordered as follows:

DocumentStyleSheetSets.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated The styleSheetSets read-only property returns a live list of all of the currently-available style sheet sets.
DocumentStyleSheetSets.value: A list of style sheet sets that are available.

DocumentTimeline.summary: The timeline readonly property of the interface represents the default timeline of the current document. This timeline is a special instance of .

remarks.para: This timeline is unique to each document and persists for the lifetime of the document including calls to .

This timeline expresses the time in milliseconds since .
Prior to the time origin, the timeline is inactive, and its is null.

blockquote.para: A document timeline that is associated with a non-active document (a not associated with a , {{htmlelement("iframe")}}, or {{htmlelement("frame")}}) is also considered to be inactive.

remarks.para:
-Web Animations API
-
-
-

DocumentTitle.summary:
The document.title property gets or sets the current title of the document.
When present, it defaults to the value of the <title>.
DocumentTitle.value:
A string containing the document's title. If the title was overridden by setting document.title, it contains that value. Otherwise, it contains the title specified in the <title> element.newTitle is the new title of the document. The assignment
affects the return value of document.title, the title displayed for the
document (e.g., in the titlebar of the window or tab), and it also affects the DOM of the
document (e.g., the content of the <title> element in an HTML
document).

DocumentURL.summary:
The URL read-only property of the
interface returns the document location as a string.

remarks.para: -The property which returns the same value.

DocumentURL.value: A string containing the URL of the document.

DocumentVisibilitychange.summary: The visibilitychange event is fired at the document when the contents of its tab have become visible or have been hidden.

remarks.para: The event is not cancelable.

-Page Visibility API
-
-
-Don't lose user and app state, use Page Visibility explains in detail why you should use visibilitychange, not beforeunload/unload.
-Page Lifecycle API gives best-practices guidance on handling page lifecycle behavior in your web applications.

DocumentVisibilityState.summary:
The Document.visibilityState
read-only property returns the visibility of the document. It can be used to check whether the document is in the background or in a minimized window, or is otherwise not visible to the user.

remarks.para: When the value of this property changes, the event is sent to the .
The property provides an alternative way to determine whether the page is hidden.

-
-Page Visibility API

DocumentVisibilityState.value: A string with one of the following values:

DocumentVlinkColor.summary:
IMPORTANT Deprecated The Document.vlinkColor property gets/sets the color of
links that the user has visited in the document.
DocumentVlinkColor.value: A string representing the color as a word (e.g., "red") or hexadecimal value (e.g., "#ff0000").When set to the null value, that null value is converted to the empty string (""), so document.vlinkColor = null is equivalent to document.vlinkColor = "".

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGUse of the document.write() method is strongly discouraged.
Avoid using it, and where possible replace it in existing code.

remarks.para: As the HTML spec itself warns:

blockquote.para:
This method has very idiosyncratic behavior.
In some cases, this method can affect the state of the HTML parser while the parser is running, resulting in a DOM that does not correspond to the source of the document (e.g., if the string written is the string "<plaintext>" or "<!--").
In other cases, the call can clear the current page first, as if had been called.
In yet more cases, the method is simply ignored, or throws an exception. Users agents are explicitly allowed to avoid executing script elements inserted via this method.
And to make matters even worse, the exact behavior of this method can in some cases be dependent on network latency, which can lead to failures that are very hard to debug.
For all these reasons, use of this method is strongly discouraged.

This API parses its input as HTML, writing the result into the DOM.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site-scripting (XSS) attacks, if the input originally came from an attacker.

For this reason it's much safer to pass only objects into this method, and to enforce this using the require-trusted-types-for CSP directive.
This means you can be sure that the input has been passed through a transformation function, which has the chance to sanitize the input to remove potentially dangerous markup, such as script elements and event handler attributes.

remarks.para: The write() method of the interface writes text in one or more or string parameters to a document stream opened by .

-
-
-
-Trusted Types API
-Cross-site scripting (XSS)

summary.blockquote:
WARNINGThis API parses its input as HTML, writing the result into the DOM.
APIs like this are known as injection sinks, and are potentially a vector for cross-site-scripting (XSS) attacks, if the input originally came from an attacker.

remarks.para:
For this reason it's much safer to pass only objects into this method, and to enforce this using the require-trusted-types-for CSP directive.
This means you can be sure that the input has been passed through a transformation function, which has the chance to sanitize the input to remove potentially dangerous markup, such as script elements and event handler attributes.
The writeln() method of the interface writes text in one or more or string parameters to a document stream opened by , followed by a newline character.

The method is essentially the same as but adds a newline (information in the linked topic also applies to this method).
This newline will only be visible if it is injected inside an element where newlines are displayed.
The additional information in also applies to this method.

DocumentXmlEncoding.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated Returns the encoding as determined by the XML declaration. Should be null if unspecified or unknown.

blockquote.para: Do not use this attribute; it has been removed from the DOM Level 4 specification and is no longer supported in Firefox 10.0.

remarks.para: Consider the following XML Declaration:
Then, the result should be "UTF-16".

DocumentXmlVersion.summary: IMPORTANT Deprecated Returns the version number as specified in the XML declaration (e.g., <?xml version="1.0"?>) or "1.0" if the declaration is absent.

remarks.para: This attribute was never really useful, since it always returned 1.0, and has been removed in DOM Level 4. As such, Firefox 10 no longer implements it. Its primary use in the past was to detect whether or not the document was being rendered as XML rather than HTML. To detect this, you can create an element with its name in lower case, then check to see if it gets converted into all upper case (in which case the document is in the non-XML HTML mode):
